In Israel, the separation of powers operates in a parliamentary system, with the government being headed by a Prime Minister and a cabinet. The Prime Minister is elected by the majority of the members of the Knesset (the legislative branch), and the cabinet is appointed by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister and the cabinet are responsible for implementing policy and running the country, while the Knesset is responsible for making laws.

The judiciary in Israel is an independent branch of government, with the Supreme Court serving as the highest court in the land. The Supreme Court has the power to interpret laws and rule on their constitutionality, and it also has the power to hear appeals in certain cases.

In practice, the separation of powers operates in a way that balances the power between the different branches of government. For example, the Knesset has the power to impeach the Prime Minister, but the Prime Minister also has the power to dissolve the Knesset and call for new elections. The Supreme Court has the power to rule on the constitutionality of laws, but it must also take into account the views of the other branches of government.

In this way, the separation of powers helps to ensure that the government acts in the best interests of the people, and that the different branches of government are able to check and balance each other to prevent abuses of power.
